explanation: The report is not correct. MISRA Rule 2.2 targets executed code whose removal would not affect program behaviour. The mhd_assert(...) invocation is not merely a pure, side‑effect‑free diagnostic in the sense required to call it dead code: when assertions are enabled the expression is evaluated and, if it fails, the assertion machinery typically produces diagnostics and/or terminates the program (i.e. it can change program behaviour). Even though MHD_str_equal_caseless_ itself appears to only read/compare (no object mutation), its evaluation participates in a runtime check that may alter control flow (logging/abort) when the condition is false. Therefore the assertion call is not removable without potentially changing behaviour and so is not “dead code” under Rule 2.2. The fact that the project can be built with assertions disabled (in which case the assertion expands away) does not make the executed assertion inherently dead in builds where it is enabled. The empty probe log from the supplied test harness is unrelated to the MISRA assessment — it only shows the test driver didn’t exercise that path and does not prove the assertion is dead code.
